meta.title: Is Your Baby Ready for Solid Foods?
meta.description: A research-backed assessment to help you determine if your baby is ready to start solid foods. Based on developmental milestones from the AAP, WHO, and CDC.
meta.intro:
Starting solids isn't about hitting a specific age — it's about watching for developmental readiness. Your baby needs the oral motor control, physical stability, and digestive maturity to handle food safely.

Answer based on what your baby does consistently, not just once or twice.

sources.name: American Academy of Pediatrics — Starting Solid Foods
World Health Organization — Infant Feeding Guidelines
CDC — When, What, and How to Introduce Solid Foods

questions.text: What happens when you put a soft spoon or teething toy near your baby's mouth?
questions.subtext: Watch how they move their tongue and jaw.

options.text: They close their lips around it and move it back with their tongue
They mouth it but push it out with their tongue sometimes
Their tongue automatically pushes everything forward and out

questions.text: Can your baby move food or a toy from one side of their mouth to the other?
questions.subtext: This lateral tongue movement is key for chewing and swallowing safely.
questions.source: WHO — oral motor development for feeding

options.text: Yes, they move things side to side in their mouth
Sometimes, but not consistently
Everything stays in the center or falls out

questions.text: Does your baby make chewing motions when watching you eat?
questions.subtext: Mimicking eating is a strong readiness signal — they're learning by watching.

options.text: Yes, they move their mouth and jaw like they're eating too
They watch intently but don't mimic yet
They don't seem interested in watching us eat

questions.text: How does your baby react when they see you eating?
questions.subtext: Interest in your food is one of the clearest readiness signs.
questions.source: CDC — signs of readiness for solids

options.text: Reaches for your food, leans in, or tries to grab it
Watches with interest but doesn't reach
Doesn't pay attention to our meals

questions.text: Is your baby still satisfied after a full milk feeding?
questions.subtext: If they're draining bottles or nursing more frequently and still seem hungry, they may be ready for more calories.

options.text: No, they seem hungry even after a full feeding
Usually satisfied, but occasionally want more
Yes, milk is still filling them up completely

questions.text: How are your baby's bowel movements?
questions.subtext: Regular, predictable digestion is a sign their gut is maturing.

options.text: Pretty regular and predictable
Somewhat irregular but not concerning
All over the place — very inconsistent

questions.text: Can your baby sit upright in a high chair or on your lap with minimal support?
questions.subtext: They don't need to sit independently yet, but their trunk should be stable enough to hold their head and torso upright.
questions.source: CDC — sitting stability for safe feeding

options.text: Yes, sits upright with steady head and trunk control
Mostly upright but needs some propping or support
Slumps over or can't hold their head steady

questions.text: Can your baby hold their head steady and upright during a feeding?
questions.subtext: Strong neck control is essential for swallowing safely.
questions.source: AAP — head control and aspiration prevention

options.text: Yes, their head stays steady the whole time
Mostly steady but wobbles a bit when tired
Head is still wobbly and needs support

questions.text: When you offer your baby a spoon of water or breastmilk, what happens?
questions.subtext: This tests whether they can pull liquid off a spoon without gagging or pushing it out.

options.text: They pull it off the spoon and swallow it smoothly
They get some in but push the spoon out with their tongue
They gag, spit it out, or it dribbles right back out

high.headline: Mouth skills are ready
high.detail: Your baby's tongue thrust reflex has faded, they can move food around in their mouth, and they're mimicking chewing. These are the oral motor skills that make eating possible — and safe.
high.strength: Strong oral motor control — your baby can manage food in their mouth and is ready to learn swallowing solids

medium.headline: Oral skills are emerging
medium.detail: Your baby is developing the oral motor control needed for solids, but it's not fully consistent yet. Letting them mouth spoons and safe teething toys helps these skills strengthen quickly.
medium.concern: Oral motor skills are still developing — practicing with spoons and safe mouthing toys will help these skills emerge

low.headline: Tongue thrust still strong
low.detail: Your baby's tongue is still pushing things forward and out of their mouth — this is the protective tongue thrust reflex. It usually fades between 4-6 months, but some babies take longer. Until it does, food will just get pushed right back out.
low.concern: The tongue thrust reflex is still active. Give it a few more weeks — this reflex usually fades on its own by 6 months.

high.headline: Curious and hungry
high.detail: Your baby is showing clear interest in your food and may not be fully satisfied by milk alone anymore. These are strong behavioral signs that they're ready to explore eating.
high.strength: Clear hunger and interest cues — your baby is signaling they're ready for more than just milk

medium.headline: Interest is growing
medium.detail: Your baby is starting to notice food, but they're not actively reaching for it or showing signs that milk isn't enough yet. This is normal — interest often comes in waves as they get closer to readiness.
medium.concern: Interest in food is emerging but not strong yet — letting them watch you eat and explore safe objects with their mouth builds curiosity

low.headline: Still content with milk
low.detail: Your baby isn't showing interest in your food and is still satisfied by milk alone. This is perfectly fine — especially if they're younger or just not developmentally ready yet. Interest will come.
low.concern: Your baby isn't signaling hunger for solids yet. No need to rush — continue with milk and watch for interest to emerge in the coming weeks.

high.headline: Digestion is stable
high.detail: Your baby's digestive system is showing signs of maturity with regular, predictable bowel movements. This suggests their gut is ready to handle the transition to solid foods.
high.strength: Digestive system is mature and stable — your baby's gut is ready for the complexity of solid foods

medium.headline: Digestion is maturing
medium.detail: Your baby's digestion is mostly stable but not completely predictable yet. This is common and doesn't prevent starting solids — just means you may see some changes in bowel movements as you introduce new foods.
medium.concern: Digestive patterns are still settling — expect some variability when you start solids, which is completely normal

low.headline: Digestion still unpredictable
low.detail: Your baby's digestive system is still figuring things out. While irregular bowel movements alone don't prevent starting solids, it's worth mentioning to your pediatrician — especially if combined with other signs of unreadiness.
low.concern: Digestive irregularity is worth monitoring. If your baby also shows other signs of unreadiness, give their gut a bit more time to mature.

high.headline: Steady and stable
high.detail: Your baby has the trunk and head control needed to sit upright during feeding. This stability is critical for safe swallowing — it keeps their airway aligned and reduces choking risk.
high.strength: Excellent sitting stability — your baby can maintain the upright position needed for safe eating

medium.headline: Sitting is improving
medium.detail: Your baby can sit with some support, but isn't completely stable yet. This is fine for early solids as long as you're propping them securely in a high chair — just watch that their head doesn't wobble during swallowing.
medium.concern: Sitting stability is developing — use good support in a high chair and watch that head control stays steady during eating

low.headline: Not ready to sit upright
low.detail: Your baby doesn't have the trunk or head control to sit upright safely yet. Feeding solids to a baby who can't hold their head steady increases choking risk. Give them a few more weeks to build this core strength.
low.concern: Sitting stability is a safety issue. Wait until your baby can hold their head and trunk steady before introducing solids.

ready.headline: Green Light!
ready.subheadline: Your baby is showing clear readiness for solid foods.
ready.explanation: Your baby has the oral motor control, physical stability, digestive maturity, and interest signals that research links to successful solid food introduction. They're ready to explore eating — and you're ready to let them.
nextSteps: Start with single-ingredient foods — avocado, banana, sweet potato — and wait 3-5 days before introducing the next one to watch for reactions
Let them touch, smush, and explore food with their hands — this is learning, not mess
Offer solids after a milk feeding at first — they'll be calmer and more willing to experiment when not ravenous
Expect most of the food to end up on the floor or in their hair — swallowing is a learned skill that takes weeks of practice
ready.watchOutFor: Gagging is normal and protective — it sounds scary but it's their body learning where food should go. Choking is silent. Learn the difference, take an infant CPR class if you haven't, and trust that gagging means their reflexes are working.
ready.encouragement: Starting solids is one of those milestones that feels huge — and it is. But it's also just the beginning of a long, messy, hilarious process. You've got this.
ready.comparativeContext: Babies who show these readiness signs typically transition to solids smoothly, though expect a learning curve in the first 2-3 weeks.
ready.retakeAdvice: No need to retake — your baby is ready to start

almost.headline: Almost There
almost.subheadline: Your baby is building readiness — a few areas could use more time.
almost.explanation: Your baby has some strong readiness signs and some areas still developing. This is common, especially for younger babies or those who haven't had much exposure to spoons or watching you eat. Look at the domain breakdown below to see where a little more time or practice could help.
nextSteps: Let your baby watch you eat — sit them in a high chair at the table even if they're not eating yet
Practice with a spoon by offering breast milk or formula on a soft baby spoon
Give them safe things to mouth and explore — silicone spoons, teething toys — to build oral motor skills
Work on sitting practice — tummy time and supported sitting build the core strength needed for safe eating
almost.watchOutFor: Don't feel pressured to start at exactly 6 months if your baby isn't showing readiness. The WHO and AAP recommend starting 'around 6 months' — which means anywhere from 5.5 to 7 months depending on the individual baby. A few weeks of extra development can make the whole process easier.
almost.encouragement: Your baby is closer than you think. The fact that you're paying attention to readiness signs instead of just starting on a calendar date means you're already setting them up for success.
almost.comparativeContext: Most babies who score in this range are ready within 2-4 weeks. Retake this quiz when you notice changes in sitting or oral motor skills.
almost.retakeAdvice: Retake this quiz in 2-3 weeks to track progress

not-yet.headline: Give It More Time
not-yet.subheadline: Your baby has room to develop before starting solids — and that's completely fine.
not-yet.explanation: Your baby isn't showing consistent readiness signs yet. This is especially common in younger babies (under 5.5 months) or those who haven't had much exposure to watching eating, handling spoons, or practicing sitting. Readiness unfolds on its own timeline — pushing it before they're ready just makes the process harder for everyone.
nextSteps: Keep offering breast milk or formula — it's still nutritionally complete until they're ready for solids
Let them watch you eat from a supported seat — just being present at meals builds interest
Work on tummy time and supported sitting to build the core strength needed for safe feeding
Talk to your pediatrician at your next visit about readiness signs and when to expect them based on your baby's development
not-yet.watchOutFor: If your baby is approaching 7 months and still isn't showing any readiness signs — especially sitting stability or reduced tongue thrust — mention it to your pediatrician. Most of the time it's just normal developmental variation, but occasionally it signals a need for extra support.
not-yet.encouragement: Your baby will get there. Readiness isn't something you teach — it's something that emerges when their body and brain are ready. You're doing exactly the right thing by waiting and watching.
not-yet.comparativeContext: Many babies who score in this range show clear readiness within 3-6 weeks. Development happens in bursts, and sitting and oral motor skills often emerge quickly once they start.
